column5: #RentFreezeNow calls for an indefinite freeze on collection of all rent, mortgage, and utility payments throughout the duration of the crisis. The freeze must operate as a waiver of payments, not a deferral in which people will find themselves saddled by debt after the crisis. Additionally, for the Circuit Court to close all court filings for evictions and foreclosures, for the city to house residents experiencing homelessness immediately, and for landlords and/or city officials to grant automatic lease extensions to tenants unable to move during the crisis.

column5: Tenants and mobile home owners to remain in their homes during the COVID-19 pandemic even if they are unable to stay current on their rent. The order also relieves courts from certain statutory restrictions to enable them to stay eviction-related proceedings until after the COVID-19 emergency has passed. The executive order takes effect immediately and will remain in effect until July 25, 2020.

column27: Landlords who don't want to renew a lease because the tenant didn't pay rent or late fees during the emergency period must FIRST give the tenant a chance to propose a reasonable repayment plan. A proposed plan is considered "reasonable" if: all missed rent would be paid back within 12 months of the agreement;  the tenant will be able to afford to make those payments on schedule; and the tenant would continue to pay their future rent in full.

column43:
These protections apply in any city in Solano County that doesn't have its own ordinance, as well as in unincorporated Solano County. It lasts for 90 days after the California state of emergency ends (currently 5/31/2020).

Tenants do NOT have to show that their inability to pay was related to COVID-19; the county will assume that everyone is affected. If a landlord wants to argue otherwise, the burden is on the landlord to show that the tenant's circumstances are not related to the pandemic.

Tenants also have the right to break any lease with 30 days' notice, without penalties, as long as the reason is related to the pandemic (e.g., they lost their job or they need to care for relatives.)

Landlords who issue notices demanding rent or late fees must include must include information about these protections; see the ordinance for the exact requirement.

column43:
If you have a letter for your landlord and can show the constable a copy, most evictions will be delayed. But itâ€™s up to the court to decide if the delay stands if the landlord appeals the delay. 

A constable CAN notify the tenant that they need to write a letter. There are very specific reasons a court can dismiss the delay: criminal activity, serious health and safety concerns, property damage or making false statements during the application process.

https://www.azcourts.gov/Portals/34/20200429EvictionGuidanceFinal.pdf

column5: The One Sioux Falls Fund was created to help local residents negatively impacted by COVID-19 in the Sioux Falls area. The fund is set up in collaboration with the Sioux Falls Area Community Foundation. The goal of the fund is to help residents in the Sioux Falls MSA (Minnehaha, Lincoln, McCook and Turner counties) avoid evictions and financial hardships if they are unable to work due to COVID-19 and if they are unable to qualify for federal or state assistance. Applicants will be required to demonstrate financial impact with appropriate documentation.

column43:
These protections apply to cities in Los Angeles County that don't have their own ordinance, as well as unincorporated Los Angeles County.

Everything in these protections also applies to mobile home owners who rent space in a mobile home park.

The rent freeze on rent-stabilized housing also bans "pass-throughs" (when landlords charge tenants to make up the cost of various expenses.)

Landlords are explicitly banned from harassing tenants based on these issues.

column5: The Metropolitan Housing Alliance has announced that public housing residents and Section 8 tenants in Little Rock will not be evicted during this time period. The housing agency will work with property management companies on rent forbearance. The housing agency is also not terminating anyone using Section 8 vouchers for housing.

column5: Moratorium on tenant evictions for residential and commercial renters. It applies to tenants who have suffered a household or business income loss of 20% or have had to pay 20% of their income in medical bills as a result of COVID-19. Elk Grove businesses with at least $25 million in gross sales would not qualify for the protection, excluding franchisees. If a renter does qualify for protection, they must still pay what they can reasonably pay at the time rent is due. The protections allow tenants who can show that they have been affected by the coronavirus up to 120 days to pay rent after the end of the emergency order. The tenant must tell their landlord of their situation before rent is due. The city also will not shut off waste or drainage services for late payments.

column43:
City of Moorpark has imposed a temporary moratorium on evictions 
for non-payment of rent by residential or commercial tenants impacted by
 the COVID-19/coronavirus crisis. Â The moratorium does not relieve 
tenants of liability for unpaid rent. Â The moratorium will initially be 
in effect until May 31.â€œAs a result of the public health 
emergency and the precautions recommended by public health authorities, 
many Moorpark residents and businesses are experiencing, or will soon 
experience, a sudden and unexpected loss of income, leaving them 
vulnerable to eviction,â€ said City Manager Troy Brown. Â â€œThe moratorium 
is intended to avoid unnecessary housing and commercial tenant 
displacement, to prevent housed individuals from falling into 
homelessness, and to protect the Cityâ€™s vulnerable businesses.â€

column5: The city has placed a moratorium on evictions for non-payment of rent for tenants who can't afford to pay because of the pandemicâ€”for example, because their hours were cut, their business closed, they were laid off, or they have extreme medical costs related to COVID-19. To be protected, tenants have 30 days after rent is due to provide written notice to the landlord (including emails of texts) that they cannot pay rent, and must provide documentation to support their claim (such as pay stubs, time cards, proof of medical care or quarantine, or notices from employers or schools). Tenants are still required to pay rent.

column5:
Notwithstanding anything to the contrary in the Goleta Municipal Code and uncodified regulations, during the period of local emergency declared in response to COVID-19, no landlord shall endeavor to evict a residential or commercial tenant for nonpayment
of rent if the tenant demonstrates that the tenant is unable to pay rent due to financial impacts related to COVID-19. A landlord who knows that a tenant cannot pay some or all of the rent temporarily for the reasons set forth above shall not serve a notice pursuant to CCP 1161(2), file or prosecute an unlawful detainer action based on a 3-day pay or quit notice, or otherwise seek to evict for nonpayment of rent. A landlord knows of a tenantâ€™s inability to pay rent within the meaning of this order if the tenant, within 30 days after the date that rent is due, notifies the landlord in writing of lost income and inability to pay full rent due to financial impacts related to COVID19, and provides documentation to support the claim. For purposes of this ordinance, â€œin writingâ€ includes email or text communications to a landlord or the landlordâ€™s representative with whom the tenant has previously corresponded by email or text. Any medical or financial information provided to the landlord shall be held in confidence, and only used for evaluating the tenantâ€™s claim.

column5: Emergency Order Establishing a Moratorium on Eviction Enforcement in the City of Somerville for the duration of the COVID-19 emergency. The order, which applies to both residential and commercial evictions and goes into effect immediately, prohibits the physical act of eviction within the city limits so as to provide for the health, safety, and stability of those who live in and serve our community. The Eviction Moratorium does not prevent owners from filing eviction cases or getting what is known as â€œexecutions for possessionâ€ from the courts. It prohibits â€œlevying,â€ which is the physical removal of persons and belongings. No landlord and/or owner shall access or seek to access a tenantâ€™s dwelling space for purposes such as general inspections, displaying units to potential future tenants and other non-critical activities. A landlord may only access a tenantâ€™s dwelling space to make repairs requested by the tenant, repairs required as a matter of law, or to respond to a life threatening emergency. A tenant may refuse access or entry for non-critical purposes or when adequate social distancing arrangements (at a minimum of six feet) have not been made. The order does not protect tenants from eviction once the Board of Health determines that the public health emergency no longer exists.

column5: The North Dakota Supreme Court suspended all residential eviction proceedings until further notice. The North Dakota Supreme Court has continued to hear cases, as have lower courts in the state. Prior to the Supreme Court taking official actions, county sheriffs in Clay, Cass, Grand Forks, and Burleigh counties all had stopped enforcing evictions. Cass County, Burleigh County, and Grand Forks County are home to the state's three largest cities, respectively Fargo, Bismarck, and Grand Forks. The ACLU of North Dakota is worried that a â€œGood Causeâ€ clause in the wording may still put renters at risk for eviction if landlords can provide reasoning for removing them from the property. There is not much documentation about this "protection" on the state website, or even in the media.

column5: Executive order pausing evictions and foreclosures until the state of emergency is over. Tenants and homeowners will still be obligated to make up the payments. Public housing authorities have also been asked to extend deadlines for eligibility requirements for public housing. Governor Eric Holcomb ordered that evictions and foreclosure actions/proceedings may not be brought March 19, 2020 until the executive order declaring a state of emergency in Indiana is halted by the governor. The Supreme Court of Indiana issued clarifying guidance that filings are still being accepted, and urging courts to consider public health, safety, and property values when using their discretion to decide whether to stay non-emergency proceedings. The governor's order also requests that public housing authorities extend deadlines for housing assistance recipients or applicants. Finally, each circuit and superior court in Indiana has issued a slightly different version suspending most civil proceedings although none of these applied explictly to eviction proceedings or foreclosures. The majority of districts suspended all civil hearings from 2 weeks up to 1.5 months while the minority of districts suspended only in person hearings/civil jury trials but allowed for teleconferencing or alternative methods for continuing non-essential business. Indiana has also placed a statewide moratorium on utility shut-offs and individual companies have announced that they will further suspend shutoffs.

column5: The city has placed a moratorium on evictions for non-payment of rent for tenants who can't afford to pay because of the pandemicâ€”for example, because their hours were cut, their business closed, they were laid off, or they have extreme medical costs related to COVID-19. To be protected, tenants have 90 days after rent is due to provide written notice to the landlord (including emails of texts) that they cannot pay rent, and must provide documentation to support their claim (such as pay stubs, time cards, proof of medical care or quarantine, or notices from employers or schools). After the order ends, tenants will have six months to make up the rent they couldn't pay during the emergency, and will not have to pay any late fees.

column5: Wisconsin Gov. Tony Evers has ordered the suspension of evictions and foreclosures during the coronavirus public health emergency. The order is effective as of March 27 and lasts for 60 days. The order stops landlords from evicting tenants "from evicting tenants for any reason unless failure to proceed with the eviction will result in an imminent threat of serious physical harm to another person and mortgagees from commencing civil action to foreclose on real estate for 60 days." The order does not relieve the obligation to pay rent or mortgage payments. The Supreme Court of Wisconsin has suspended in person hearings statewide and is requiring the use of technology in lieu of in person courtroom appearances. Wisconsin has directed court personnel to conduct proceedings using technology but has not cancelled or continued proceedings generally and left discretion to local courts. Some county circuit courts have postponed many types of hearings, often including eviction cases. In some locations, however, circuit courts have specified that evictions will proceed, in some cases noting that appearances should occur by telephone. There is a statutory time limit in Wisconsin for scheduling hearings after a party has raised a defense in an eviction action. (Wis. Stat. 799.206) In Wisconsin, evictions are small claims cases.

column5: Landlords cannot evict renters impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic during this period of local emergency. The tenant must provide written notice to the landlord regarding inability to pay rent because of lost income and financial impacts due to COVID-19 no later than 10 days after the rent due date. The tenant must provide documentation of COVID-19 financial impacts within 30 days of the rent due date. Residential landlords may not initiate a no-fault eviction unless immediately necessary because of a hazardous condition (which would not include any condition related to COVID-19). Other provisions of the ordinance are: â€¢The tenant shall pay the portion of the rent the tenant is able to pay. â€¢The tenant is not relieved of liability for unpaid rent, which the landlord may seek after the expiration of the local emergency. â€¢The tenant must pay back rent within six months of the expiration of the local emergency.

column5: Tenants would have to notify their landlords before rent is due that they cannot pay the full rent amount because of a covered reason, and instead pay as much rent as they can. Renters would then have up to 120 days, or roughly four months, after Californiaâ€™s state of emergency declaration is removed to pay back the deferred rent. Tenants would have to provide documentation to landlords that theyâ€™ve lost income because: â–ª They were sick with, or caring for a family member sick with COVID-19. â–ª They experienced a layoff, loss of hours or other income reduction resulting from COVID-19 or the state of emergency. â–ª They were complying with a recommendation from a government agency to stay home, self quarantine or avoid congregating with others during the state of emergency. â–ª They needed to miss work to care for a home-bound school-age child.

column5:
Under the Berkeley COVID-19 Emergency Response Ordinance, landlords cannot evict or attempt to evict a commercial or residential occupant for: Nonpayment of rent, where the occupant demonstrates nonpayment is due to the Coronavirus, the Coronavirus state of emergency, or after complying with a government Coronavirus precaution; or,
No-fault evictions of a residential tenant, except when necessary for the health and safety of tenants, neighbors, or the landlord. To gain these critical tenant protections, Berkeley tenants who suffer Coronavirus-related income disruption must, in writing, notify their landlords of their income disruption, and resultant inability to pay rent. Further, the tenant must attach documentation of their income disruption or COVID-19 out-of-pocket medical expense, such as a medical bill, paystubs, or letter from an employer indicating that the tenant has suffered reduced hours or lost wages due to the Coronavirus.  Where a landlord knows that a tenant cannot pay all or some of their rent due to the Coronavirus, the Berkeley COVID-19 Emergency Response Ordinance also prohibits landlords from serving notices to pay rent or quit, initiating a related eviction action in court, or prosecuting said eviction action. After the Coronavirus state of emergency ceases, a landlord has the right to collect unpaid rent; However, the landlord may not charge or collect a late fee for the unpaid rent

column5: The San Mateo County Board of Supervisors unanimously enacted an emergency eviction moratorium to temporarily protect tenants from being displaced from their homes during the ongoing COVID-19 public health crisis. Protects eligible tenants against COVID-19 related nonpayment of rent and no-fault evictions. Tenants must inform landlords of non-payment and provide documentation within 14 days after landlord gives written notice of tenants' right to make a delayed payment. Tenants must offer supporting documentation to show they cannot pay the amount of rent due because they were impacted by COVID-19. They will have 90-180 days after the declaration of a public health emergency has ended to pay back the full amount of rent owed.

column5:
Landlords can file for eviction at any time. But no new eviction cases will go to court until 8/29/2020, and tenants do not have to file a response until then. In pending cases, court dates will not be set until 60 days after the trial is requested. Court dates that were already scheduled will also be postponed for at least 60 days. (Note: This policy does not apply to evictions deemed necessary for public health and safety.)

When cases resume, some California tenants will have a defense in court against evictions for non-payment of rent. This ONLY covers tenants who paid rent in March and can show that the reason they couldn't pay in April was related to the COVID-19 pandemic.

column5: On March 29, the governor announced a 90-day emergency moratorium on evictions and foreclosures related to defaulting on payments. The directive applies to both residential and commercial tenants. The only exception is for tenants deemed to endanger the public, be engaged in criminal activity, or cause severe property damage. Note that this exception can NOT be used to evict tenants who have been diagnosed with or exposed to COVID-19.
column13:
If landlords and tenants agree to a repayment plan, they should do so within 30 days of this order's end.  

When seeking rental assistance, tenants can use any written notice from the landlord about their missed rentâ€”not just a seven-day notice, as usualâ€”to demonstrate that they're eligible for assistance.

column5: Governor Kate Brown has strengthened previous orders. As of April 1, there is a 90-day moratorium on serving evictions to commercial and residential tenants. The order only bars police from enforcing evictions due to nonpayment of rent for a period of ninety days, but evictions for failing a rental inspection, noise complaints or any other thing deemed as a lease violation may still be served. The order makes no space for a longer repayment schedule while numerous banks have publicly given 12-month extensions to their mortgage holders, nor does this order address the need for a Nationwide Rent Freeze or Suspension to keep out of work renters from accruing mass amounts of debt.

column43:
In addition to rent, tenants are protected from eviction for not paying late fees, utility charges, or any other charges. There are also protections for commercial tenants.

This order is an expansion of a previous order barring law enforcement from enforcing evictions, available here: https://www.oregon.gov/gov/Documents/executive_orders/eo_20-11.pdf

column5: The city has placed a moratorium on evictions for non-payment of rent for tenants who can't afford to pay because of the pandemicâ€”for example, because their hours were cut, their business closed, they were laid off, or they have extreme medical costs related to COVID-19. To be protected, tenants have 30 days after rent is due to provide written notice to the landlord (including emails of texts) that they cannot pay rent, and must provide documentation to support their claim (such as pay stubs, time cards, proof of medical care or quarantine, or notices from employers or schools). Tenants are still required to pay rent.
